title: 112_hr3829
content: The "Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012" or the "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires a criminal background check for child care providers under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates a criminal background check for child care staff and providers, including a search of the National Sex Offender Registry. The Protection and Safety Act of 2006 requires background checks for individuals working with children, including searches of national and state criminal registries, as well as abuse and neglect databases. The Protection and Safety Act of 2006 mandates background checks for child care providers, including FBI fingerprint checks for individuals residing in the provider's home. Ineligibility for funds is determined by adult felony convictions for child abuse, neglect, or spousal abuse. The Protection and Safety Act of 2006 requires background checks for child care providers, including FBI fingerprint checks for individuals living in the provider's home. Ineligibility for funds is based on adult felony convictions for child abuse, neglect, spousal abuse, crimes against children, violent crimes, and drug offenses within the past 5 years. Child care providers must submit a request for a State and national criminal background check for staff members and individuals residing in their home. Child care providers must request criminal background checks for staff members, family providers, and adults residing in their home every 5 years. Child care providers must request criminal background checks for staff members, family providers, and adults residing in their home every 5 years, starting from the date of enactment. Child care providers must request criminal background checks for staff members, family providers, or adults residing in their home every 5 years. Limitation on requests: only one request is needed for each individual for a 5-year period. Results must be provided within 10 business days of the request being made to the appropriate State agency. Child care providers must request criminal background checks for staff members, family providers, or adults residing in their home every 5 years. Results of the background check must be provided by the State agency to the requester. Upon request, a copy of the background check must be given to the child care provider or individual subject to the check. States must ensure the accuracy of the information included in the background check. To ensure accuracy in background checks, steps include obtaining dispositions of arrests over 1 year old, correcting known inaccuracies, completing incomplete entries, and taking additional measures to improve information accuracy. Appeals process is also available. The appeals process allows child care providers or individuals to appeal the results of a criminal background check within 30 days to the designated State agency. The State must make a final ruling within 30 days of the appeal. The State must determine the individual's eligibility, provide specific appeal findings, update inaccurate criminal records if needed, and report changes to the individual. Fees may be charged to cover administrative costs. To cover the costs of required criminal background checks, a State can charge a fee not exceeding $36 per child care provider. States must comply with the section's requirements within 3 years of its enactment. The Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 allows the Secretary to grant a 2-year extension to States making a good faith effort to meet the requirements. Definitions include 'adult' as a person over 18 and 'child care provider' as various types of child care services. The Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 defines a child care provider as a person who provides child care services for compensation on a regular basis, excluding family members, and is licensed, regulated, or funded under State law. A child care staff member is an individual who provides child care services for compensation on a regular basis. The term 'family child care provider' refers to an individual who provides child care services for fewer than 24 hours per day, as the sole caregiver, in a private residence, and is not related to all the children for whom services are provided. Authorization of Appropriations To Conduct Criminal Background Checks: Sums are authorized to offset administrative costs for State and national criminal background checks.
